trans-unit.source: Load sample data into SQL Data Warehouse | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Load sample data into SQL Data Warehouse | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Load ample data into SQL Data Warehouse
trans-unit.target: Load ample data into SQL Data Warehouse

trans-unit.source: Now that you have set-up a SQL Data Warehouse instance you can easily load some sample data into it.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have set-up a SQL Data Warehouse instance you can easily load some sample data into it.

trans-unit.source: The following will help you create a dataset called AdventureWorksPDW2012 in your database.
trans-unit.target: The following will help you create a dataset called AdventureWorksPDW2012 in your database.

trans-unit.source: This dataset models out a sample data warehouse structure for a fictional company called AdventureWorks.
trans-unit.target: This dataset models out a sample data warehouse structure for a fictional company called AdventureWorks.

trans-unit.source: Note that you will need to have BCP installed for the following steps.
trans-unit.target: Note that you will need to have BCP installed for the following steps.

trans-unit.source: If you do not currently have BCP installed, please install the <linkText>Microsoft Command Line Utilities for SQL Server</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you do not currently have BCP installed, please install the <linkText>Microsoft Command Line Utilities for SQL Server</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To get started click to download our <linkText>Sample Data Scripts</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To get started click to download our <linkText>Sample Data Scripts</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: After the file has downloaded, extract the contents of the AdventureWorksPDW2012.zip file and open the new AdventureWorksPDW2012 folder.
trans-unit.target: After the file has downloaded, extract the contents of the AdventureWorksPDW2012.zip file and open the new AdventureWorksPDW2012 folder.

trans-unit.source: Edit the aw_create.bat file and set the following values at the top of the file:
trans-unit.target: Edit the aw_create.bat file and set the following values at the top of the file:

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: Server: The fully qualified name of the server your SQL Data Warehouse resides on
trans-unit.target: Server: The fully qualified name of the server your SQL Data Warehouse resides on

trans-unit.source: b.
trans-unit.target: b.

trans-unit.source: User: The user for the above server
trans-unit.target: User: The user for the above server

trans-unit.source: c.
trans-unit.target: c.

trans-unit.source: Password: The password for the provided server log-in
trans-unit.target: Password: The password for the provided server log-in

trans-unit.source: d.
trans-unit.target: d.

trans-unit.source: Database: The name of the SQL Data Warehouse instance you wish to load data onto
trans-unit.target: Database: The name of the SQL Data Warehouse instance you wish to load data onto

trans-unit.source: Ensure that there is no whitespace between the '=' and these parameters.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that there is no whitespace between the '=' and these parameters.

trans-unit.source: Run aw_create.bat from the directory in which it is located.
trans-unit.target: Run aw_create.bat from the directory in which it is located.

trans-unit.source: This will create the schema and load data into all the tables using BCP.
trans-unit.target: This will create the schema and load data into all the tables using BCP.

trans-unit.source: As described in the <linkText>connect and query</linkText><title></title> documentation you can connect to this database using Visual Studio and SSDT.
trans-unit.target: As described in the <linkText>connect and query</linkText><title></title> documentation you can connect to this database using Visual Studio and SSDT.

trans-unit.source: Now that you've loaded some sample data into your SQL Data Warehouse, you can quickly run a few queries to get started.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've loaded some sample data into your SQL Data Warehouse, you can quickly run a few queries to get started.

trans-unit.source: We can run a simple select statement to get all the info of the employees:
trans-unit.target: We can run a simple select statement to get all the info of the employees:

trans-unit.source: We can also run a more complex query using constructs such as GROUP BY to look at the total amount for all sales on each day:
trans-unit.target: We can also run a more complex query using constructs such as GROUP BY to look at the total amount for all sales on each day:

trans-unit.source: We can even use the WHERE clause to filter out orders from before a certain date:
trans-unit.target: We can even use the WHERE clause to filter out orders from before a certain date:

trans-unit.source: In fact, SQL Data Warehouse supports almost all of the T-SQL constructs that SQL Server does, and you can find some of the differences in our <linkText>migrate code</linkText><title></title> documentation.
trans-unit.target: In fact, SQL Data Warehouse supports almost all of the T-SQL constructs that SQL Server does, and you can find some of the differences in our <linkText>migrate code</linkText><title></title> documentation.

trans-unit.source: Now that we've given you some time to warm up with the sample data check out how to <linkText>develop</linkText><title></title>, <linkText>load</linkText><title></title>, or <linkText>migrate</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Now that we've given you some time to warm up with the sample data check out how to <linkText>develop</linkText><title></title>, <linkText>load</linkText><title></title>, or <linkText>migrate</linkText><title></title>.
